tn.text: This means to prepare your family and those in charge of your affairs so that they know what to do after you die. This can be written clearly. AT: "You should tell the people in your palace what you want them to do after you die" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This idiom means to remember. AT: "remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Here "walk" means to "live." The phrase means to live in a way the pleases Yahweh. AT: "faithfully lived before you" or "faithfully served you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here the "heart" refers to the inner-being which represents a person's complete devotion. AT: "with all my inner being" (UDB) or "with my complete devotion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: what was good in your sight
tn.text: This phrase "in your sight" refers to what Yahweh thinks. AT: "what pleases you" or "what you consider to be good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. It is used to ask the listener to pay attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"15 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: the hand of the king of Assyria
tn.text: Here the king's "hand" refers to his power. AT: "the power of the king of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh continues speaking to Hezekiah.
This is an idiom. Yahweh uses this word to draw the listener's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These stairs are referred to this way because they were built while Ahaz was king. You can make this information clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"that before I have grown old." This refers to dying at middle age, before growing old.

tn.ref: I will go through the gates of Sheol
tn.text: This speaks of dying as if Sheol were a kingdom that has gates that one enters. AT: "I will die and go to Sheol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I am sent there for the rest of my years
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "before I have lived all of my years I will go to the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in the land of the living
tn.text: "The living" refers to people who are alive. AT: "in the land where people are alive" or "in this world where people are alive" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
Hezekiah continues his written prayer.

tn.ref: My life is removed and carried away from me like a shepherd's tent
tn.text: This speaks of how Yahweh is ending Hezekiah's life quickly by comparing it to how a shepherd removes his tent from the ground. AT: "Yahweh has taken my life away from me quickly like a shepherd packs up his tent and carries it away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh has taken my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I have rolled up my life like a weaver; you are cutting me off from the loom
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh quickly ending Hezekiah's life by comparing it to how a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom and rolls it up. AT: "you are ending my life quickly, like a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom when it is finished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here "you" is singular and refers to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_yousingular]])
a device used to weave thread together to make cloth

tn.ref: like a lion he breaks all my bones
tn.text: Hezekiah speaks of how he is in extreme pain by comparing it to having his body torn apart by lions. AT: "my pain was as though I were being torn apart by lions" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Hezekiah continues his written prayer.

tn.ref: Like a swallow I chirp; I coo like a dove
tn.text: Both of these clauses mean the same thing and they emphasize how sad and pitiful Hezekiah's cries were. A swallow and a dove are types of birds. AT: "My cries are pitiful--they sound like the chirp of a swallow and the coo of a dove" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here Hezekiah refers to himself my his "eyes" to emphasize that he is looking for something. AT: "I" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This refers to Hezekiah looking to heaven for God to help him. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear.  AT: "of waiting for help to come from heaven" or "of waiting for you to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "My sickness oppresses me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Hezekiah uses a question to emphasize he has nothing left to say. This can be written as a statement. AT: "I have nothing left to say." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is an idiom. Here "walking" refers to living. AT: "I will like humbly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to the rest of his life. The meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "the rest of my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: because I am overcome with grief
tn.text: "because I am full of grief" or "because I am very sad"
Hezekiah continues his written prayer.

tn.ref: may my life be given back to me
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "may you give my life back to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Hezekiah did not die but he was close to dying. This refers Yahweh saving him from dying. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "from dying and going to the pit of destruction" or "so that I did not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: for you have thrown all my sins behind your back
tn.text: Hezekiah speaks of Yahweh forgiving his sins as if they were objects that Yahweh threw behind himself and forgot about. AT: "for you have forgiven all my sins and no longer think about them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Hezekiah continues his written prayer.

tn.ref: For Sheol does not thank you; death does not praise you
tn.text: Here "Sheol" and "death" refer to "dead people." AT: "For those in Sheol do not thank you; dead people do not praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: those who go down into the pit
tn.text: "those who go down to the grave"

tn.ref: do not hope in your trustworthiness
tn.text: "do not have hope in your faithfulness." Here "your" is singular and refers to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_yousingular]])

tn.ref: The living person, the living person
tn.text: Hezekiah repeats this phrase to emphasize that only a living person, not a dead person, can give thanks to Yahweh. ([[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Hezekiah continues his written prayer.
This refers to him being saved from dying. It can be made more explicit. AT: "save me from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "we" refers to Hezekiah and the people of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. This gives background information about Isaiah and Hezekiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Let Hezekiah's servants"
This was used as an ointment. The meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "use an ointment of mashed figs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a painful area on the skin that is infected
